Look, what is so exciting about quantum computing? Why should people look at this as a theme that is exciting and investable and ripe for growth?
Yeah, I mean, so I think quantum computing can transform all of these, like, you know, things and, and, and evolution and innovations that we're all talking about right now, right? Like you have cloud computing.
You have data mining, you have the chat bots, you have research and data being done for drug companies. So quantum computers, quantum computers essentially, you know, allow allows data to process in two different states.
And it allows this to happen very quickly faster than, you know, any other traditional computer can do a computation.
So if you just think about things like, you know, biomedical research, like cancer readers, all of this data has to be processed and has to be, you know, kind of parsed and has to be delivered.
And so if you have a computer that's working, you know, and I just kind of like know a lot of people who do this for a living, right, and they might do cancer research.
And so they'll kind of go out to, you know, a huge computer in Minnesota, and it'll take like seven days to process the data that they need in order to, you know, to do whatever particular research thing you're doing.
And a quantum computer can do that in like a second, right? And so I think, you know, one of the issues and like why it's kind of not mainstream now is it's still an R&D, right?
So the computers have been known to, you know, like make errors or, you know, they're trying to kind of like sort out what the outputs will be.

And so what I think will happen is that with with AI and you need data and you need, you know, that data to produce the correct information for the query that is being asked.

I think, you know, quantum computers can really like change all of that, make it kind of like work faster and more efficiently.

to debate back and forth whether whether or not it's a good idea, and then some, you know, some make sure it would launch it, it would have a $3.
And we missed the vote, you know, so I think, you know, like speed is your weapon for sure. So, I think I think speed and being relentless about scouring the market, what's missing, what isn't out there, what is out there.
I think really giving up on, like, egos or anything that has to do with, like, I thought that was a great idea and it didn't work, you know, if it didn't work close it move on, like when you're a startup company, and people might criticize this comment,
but I think that when you're a startup and you're, you know, you're very focused on balance sheet and, and you want to build a profitable company both for your investors and, and, you know, for the people who hold your products and, and for yourselves, you have to cut your losses, right?
If an ETF comes out and it's been out for a year and people haven't treated the share of it, you know, you have to kind of close up shop as a startup and think of something new.
I think bigger, you know, bigger issuers have a little more leniency in that stage.
So I would just say, you know, be manic about watching your balance sheet speed if you have a good idea, you know, but bet bet on yourself get it to market.
And being relentless about products, like we had a product that was, you know, not performing well and we changed the methodology.
So I think just always trying to, you know, make sure you have the most efficient versions of your products out there, kind of your losses, managing your balance sheet really well and, and, you know, just being relentless about knowing that your competition is at your heels and ETF industry.
And, and how do you guys think about, you know, distribution and marketing because, again, being small and being balanced sheet conscious marketing and distribution is expensive.

And so, can you talk about how you guys really focused on brand and how you worked on kind of marketing and distribution early on to get that brand recognition?

We built our own marketing, SaaS company, you know, digital marketing are, you know, in house advertising and house distribution, AI distribution.

And we, we found, you know, the best tech and marketing expert and his name is, you know, Jacob, he runs the marketing company and, you know, Matt tasked him with basically building the best and most robust marketing distribution platform and company that would, would market our ETFs.
And so we started to your point, we started having success with getting our brand out there and then other ETF companies would call us and say, like, how on earth are you guys, how are you doing this? Like, you can't possibly have any money or so small, you have like two or three ETFs.
And then they offered to hire us to do their marketing.
And so, you know, we, we do marketing for some of the top ETF providers in the marketplace right now and that ended up turning into a business and so we separated it out from, because it was just kind of under defiance ETFs originally, we separated it out now.
And so, you know, we have our own marketing company, we do marketing for ourselves and we do marketing for other ETF issuers, other, you know, massive asset managers.
